In 2003, the Human Genome Project finished
a monumental scientific achievement:

5.54.text: the first complete human genome map.

9.46.text:
A couple of decades later, and you can get
a genetic test done

13.06.text:
by spitting in a tube and paying
a couple of hundred dollars.

16.93.text:
But that's not quite
what I'm here to talk about.

19.83.text:
This is CUBRIC, one of the most advanced
brain imaging centres in Europe,

24.05.text:
and here they’re not scanning genomes:
they’re scanning connectomes.

30.90.text:
The 'connectome' is a phrase that was coined
several years ago

35.33.text: and it's to really encapsulate the idea of

37.46.text:
mapping all the connections in the brain,
in one go.

40.12.text:
Those connections are formed by what we call
the white matter in the brain.

43.21.text: So we know the brain has grey matter,

47.24.text:
We're also really interested in what we call
the microstructure,

50.26.text:
being able to differentiate between
the size and shapes of cells

53.76.text:
that may be only
a thousand of a millimetre across.

56.59.text: What this scanner will enable us to do

58.25.text:
is to get information about differences across
the whole brain

61.59.text:
in a way that would only previously be possible
post-mortem.

64.60.text: Now, I’d be getting a scan myself, but alas,

66.74.text: I have a bit too much metal in my body.

69.68.text:
Don't worry about me or the camera getting
sucked into this, though,

72.07.text:
this is just the simulator
that they train on.

73.86.text: There's no actual magnets in there.

This MRI scanner,
the magnetic field gradient allows you

80.59.text: to be sensitive to the motion of water molecules

83.25.text:
over a distance of about
a thousandth of a millimetre.

90.13.text: then we have to fit it to mathematical models,

92.21.text: then we have to reconstruct those pathways.

And so we rapidly expand from
a few hundreds of megabytes

99.80.text:
All the hopeful science fiction fans out there
shouldn’t get too excited:

103.93.text:
in the same way as copying someone’s genome
doesn't let you make an actual copy of them,

107.99.text:
just a baby that’s an identical twin and
that doesn't know anything,

112.15.text:
scanning a connectome doesn’t mean that
you can suddenly upload someone into a computer.

116.75.text:
Scanners like this generate
road maps, not satellite photos.

120.73.text: Heck of a road map, though.

121.90.text: I think we're a long way from being able

123.49.text:
to identify differences in personality at
the present time,

127.06.text:
but that's not to say we won't be able to
do it in the future.

129.12.text:
Generally, people are connected
in the same ways,

131.13.text:
but it's subtle differences in the shapes
of the tracks

133.68.text: that does seem to be highly reproducible.

135.07.text:
If we scan 300 people, and then scan one of
those people just one more time,

140.65.text:
you can easily identify them
out of that 300 people.

143.77.text:
Essentially, any neurological or psychiatric
disease that you can think of,

147.81.text:
they're all symptoms of
malfunction of the brain.

150.54.text:
And we know that function of the brain relies
on information transfer

155.53.text:
We can say things such as "there's something
different with the integrity of the white matter".

160.14.text:
Potentially, if you can name a neurological
or psychiatric disease,

163.36.text: the information that we get from this scanner

165.20.text:
is going to be a boon
and give us major new insights.

167.82.text:
And if we could bring
the cost of the technology down,

170.06.text: you could go in for your connectome scan,

172.74.text:
and have the personalised treatment tailored
to your specific connectomic deficit.

177.20.text:
Right now connectome scans are cumbersome
and expensive,

180.29.text: and they take a long time to process and visualise.

183.43.text:
But that was true of genome scans
just 20 years ago.

187.19.text:
In a decade or two, connectome research might
unlock just as many benefits for the world.
